An intern lost part of the RSA private key when emailing the encrypted message 8270709395542277549065033394776954989329936489632649976082137804776873880529561330650994502276585301094688165903348936505424204160585292665670512262678947. Can you exploit the partial key exposure to recover the original secret?

The flag format is flag{...}
n=8407338186007196756261914350850071300797906063717494885542147724000042806481856861612931402594555357520816103202574596710335216050132322207055510434714907, e=6148887234443932621136952757024961325015652745986752519437975927762026415820123497129480648329166317489020818762941918232737097465108747443028538649014659, partial_p=13137663591268503789

---

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{h36xg1f2}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 8270709395542277549065033394776954989329936489632649976082137804776873880529561330650994502276585301094688165903348936505424204160585292665670512262678947
vulnerability: partial key exposure
hint: A partial exposure of a prime number's bits can significantly weaken RSA security. Look into lattice-based techniques like Coppersmith's attack.
